author: Somit Sinha

text:
haven't got to the point in the lecture, but I am a recent PhD graduate in a bio field.

The simple answer to that is if it was somehow self destructive and had no balancing benefit to at least cancel or balance the negative effects, any such tendency would be negatively selected against.

You'll be left with neutral behaviors and beneficial behaviors competing with each other for dominance through positive effects.

It isn't foolproof or intelligent enough to avoid creating cognitive biases or blind-spots though, its really more of a survival thing. Sometimes its better to assume for survival purposes that there is a snake in the grass or a tiger behind the bush even when its just the wind, because paranoia makes survival more likely than a completely investigative spirit would.

The brain gets around this for things that don't have immediately cognitively obvious benefits and rewards by having built-in reward mechanisms via the emotional subsystems and at a lower level a system specifically dedicated to reward/punishment (pain/pleasure and emotion have a lot to do with how memories form and how well they are stored)﻿

author: Mukul Karmakar

text:
Having no course overview is annoying as hell, so I copied all descriptions. Hope that helps!

1 an overview of the course in this introductory meeting.
2 linear regression, gradient descent, and normal equations and discusses how they relate to machine learning. 
3  locally weighted regression, probabilistic interpretation and logistic regression and how it relates to machine learning. 
4 Newton's method, exponential families, and generalized linear models and how they relate to machine learning. 
5 generative learning algorithms and Gaussian discriminative analysis and their applications in machine learning. 
6 naive Bayes, neural networks, and support vector machine. 
7 optimal margin classifiers, KKT conditions, and SUM duals. 
8 support vector machines, including soft margin optimization and kernels. 
9  learning theory, covering bias, variance, empirical risk minimization, union bound and Hoeffding's inequalities. 
10 learning theory by discussing VC dimension and model selection. 
11 Bayesian statistics, regularization, digression-online learning, and the applications of machine learning algorithms. 
12 unsupervised learning in the context of clustering, Jensen's inequality, mixture of Gaussians, and expectation-maximization. 
13 expectation-maximization in the context of the mixture of Gaussian and naive Bayes models, as well as factor analysis and digression.
14  factor analysis and expectation-maximization steps, and continues on to discuss principal component analysis (PCA). 
15 principal component analysis (PCA) and independent component analysis (ICA) in relation to unsupervised machine learning. 
16  reinforcement learning, focusing particularly on MDPs, value functions, and policy and value iteration. 
17  reinforcement learning, focusing particularly on continuous state MDPs, discretization, and policy and value iterations.
18 state action rewards, linear dynamical systems in the context of linear quadratic regulation, models, and the Riccati equation, and finite horizon MDPs.
19  debugging process, linear quadratic regulation, Kalmer filters, and linear quadratic Gaussian in the context of reinforcement learning. 
20 POMDPs, policy search, and Pegasus in the context of reinforcement learning.﻿

author: Mukarram Teacher

text:
Hello, I was wondering if someone could help me. I have a specific situation to which I would like to apply a machine learning algorithm, but I'm not sure  which one to use.

Let's say I have data from a bunch of transactions. I buy items and then resell them for a profit. So I have 4 main inputs for each transaction - 1)the amount of time it took me to buy the item, 2)the price I bought it for (relative to its market price, e.g. 0.97 or 97%), 3)the amount of time it took me to sell the item, 4)the price i sold it for (e.g. 103% of market price).

So basically I'm looking for an algorithm that can tell me what buy price and what sell price should give me the most profit per unit of time. If I buy very low, I may make more profit off the transaction but it will take longer to find a seller. Same with selling - if I sell too high it will take a long time. I need to find that sweet spot.﻿
author: Jordan Shackelford

text: I would look into some kind of logistic regression approach, maybe with stochastic flavours, depending on your setup.﻿
author: Mihai Ilie

text:
First you would have to find out if you can apply machine learning to the problem. In some cases there is not much correlation between features and the model has low accuracy for prediction purposes. I am more familiar with the R package randomForest. Here I would say you have to aim at at least an accuracy of 80% to consider the model tuned and optimal to draw predictions.

If you have historical data about the dependent and independent variables I can look at it for you in R and tell you if the problem is fit for prediction analysis﻿

author: dinesh kumar

text:
As a first thought, I have an easy way to solve this.

There are two sweet spots that we would like to find. One is the sellPrice per unit of time. The other is the buyPrice per unit of time.
I’ll explain my solution for sellPrice. Then for buyPrice it is just the same idea.

First, generate a new column in your dataset “sellPricePerUT” calculated as sellPrice/sellTime. So each sellPrice,sellTime pair will have a corresponding sellPricePerUT.

Second, plot a graph of sellPricePerUT versus sellPrice. I think the problem is getting clearer to you here. We want to sell at a high “price per unit of time”. So we just want to maximize sellPricePerUT.
At this point, you still cannot make conclusions because you might have multiple points over each other so you need to account for that.

So third, perform polynomial regression where you have a single input feature “sellPrice” and a single output feature “sellPricePerUT”. Draw the graph with the regression curve.

Conclusion Step: You can now look at the graph and observe the local and global maximum/maxima. Look at the X axis to see the sellPrice that corresponds to the maximum value. If you want to be accurate you can use a function that finds the maxima of your regression curve.

For buyPrice, you just need to look for the minimum buyPricePerUT instead of the maximum.

By the way, can you share the data set with me?﻿

author: Jules Wombat

text:
Depends on if you want to learn ML at a practical level or at an academic level. If you plan on getting good enough at ML to get a job in the field then you'll want to take the practical route, but if you want to learn ML just for the sake of understanding it or doing research then you'll want to go the academic route. Andrew's lectures are highly academic and focus a lot on the mathematical and statistical aspects of ML so unless you have a solid foundation of statistics and linear algebra basics you'll struggle to keep up. Additionally, if you follow his lectures on Coursera then you'll want to learn MATLAB as well as that's the programming language used there. MATLAB is great for prototyping when coming up with your own ML scenarios or algorithms but it's not all that practical for field work (i.e developing an ML application, gathering and managing massive amounts of data, etc.). But the good thing about Andrew's lectures is that he's incredibly well versed in the subject and could explain its concepts much better than almost anyone else I've found online. If you get through one of his courses you'll have a thorough understanding of how most ML algorithms work and that'll form a solid foundation for practical application.

However, if you want to study ML for the sake of deploying applications or getting a job then there are other available courses online which focus heavily on getting you to apply ML to real world scenarios as soon as possible. One such series is Google's own newly started Intro to Machine Learning (https://goo.gl/lIuJb2). They use Python to get you up and running coding your first ML program asap. However, the series is not complete and they are still adding to it at the time of writing. Another great source, in my opinion, is Sentdex's tutorials (https://goo.gl/RteOHz). He has a large number of tutorial series focused on implementing ML using Python which are aimed at solving practical, everyday problems like stock market predictions. These tutorials mainly focus on using already-available Python libraries (such as Sklearn and MatPlotLib) to implement ML algorithms instead of trying to build them from scratch. Mastering Sklearn and similar libraries will enable you to land an ML job much more quickly, but if you don't follow through with the academic side then you'll be left implementing a bunch of pre-written algorithms that you don't quite understand.

"Another good tip I got was to continue with reading some book on machine learning"

Good tip indeed,  you may want to find an ML book which uses the language of your choice, though if you are going to enter the fields of ML and data science Python and R are outright expected of you. One suggestion I can make is Machine Learning for Hackers by Drew Conway and John Myles White which uses R, if you want Python there's Programming Collective Intelligence by Toby Segaran , It'll help you get started but I've heard that the second book has become outdated because it uses outdated API's for pulling data from various sites. 

"picking a problem there that seemed fun"

Almost any problem becomes fun with ML but the real challenge, which is constant across all problems, is the pains of acquiring data, labelling data, formatting data, normalizing data, etc so that your algorithm can properly parse it.

"create a machine learning algorithm"

Wouldn't recommend you start implementing your own ML algorithms at this early stage, instead get to know the existing ML techniques and understand how they work, take them apart and see what each part, each variable does. Pretty much all problems you'll encounter in the real world will fall into an already defined category such as Clustering, Labelling etc, each having its own set of ML algorithms that best suite the occasion. (Here is a nifty little chart which can help you pick an appropriate algorithm: https://goo.gl/yMKQt6). These algorithms are highly optimized and quick, much better than anything we could implement manually. However, if you do encounter a problem where the existing algorithms fail to deliver a satisfactory result then you can look into forming your own ML algorithms, but this is more or less heavily research oriented. 

Hope this long post was of some help to you and good luck :)﻿

text: You are probably using machine learning in your day to day life already. Google, Amazon, Netflix, Facebook, Linkedin etc use machine learning to predict the kind of stuff you like, or to give the results that you desire, or the people you may know. Banks use it to decide credit lines etc to give to a person. Games use it to teach NPC's for AI. Genetic research involves machine learning. and probably many more fields use machine learning. It's quite a fascinating course. I just got into machine learning. Just look up videos about how games can be played by computer using machine learning. Youtube for key words like "mario machine learning" or "Flappy Bird reinforcement learning" etc. You will be hooked onto machine learning even though it's difficult. I found google deepmind and deepdream and now for about three days, I am surfing the internet for machine learning stuff even though I know nothing about it lol. I registered for more than 4 machine learning courses already. Have fun with it. :D﻿

author: Herr Frau

text:
This video is 7 years old.  Stanford should update this class video.  The instructor should probably switch to Python and R because they are free and more readily available for everyone.  While MatLab does have a home version, if you bought all of their add-on modules, it would cost you over $2,000.  Other inexpensive alternatives are Home editions of Mathematica and Maple, both of which cost under $300.

However, there has been an explosive increase in the number of Python and R users.  This means Python and R development has also been explosive.  Mathematica is a closed, proprietary system.  Maple has not been adopted as much as Mathematica.  Therefore, Python and R are the better alternatives.﻿

text: What is the difference between these lectures and the class on Coursera? Is the Coursera class as watered down as people claim?﻿
author: Lemuel Uhuru

text: I took the Coursera class and the lessons were very good and the homework problems were challenging and reflected the lesson content, and required a fair amount of skill with Matlab/Octave to solve. Most of the homework problems included "skeleton" solution code to cut the time to complete them. From some of the forum discussions I've seen, the Coursera classes may have skipped some topics in the YouTube lectures. I haven't looked at all of the YouTube lectures so I can't verify this. The class included many PDF reference papers. What you call "watered down" means that some topics may have been omitted to fit it into the ten week Coursera limit, but the individual lessons were very complete.﻿
author: Bob Crunch

text: +Bob Crunch  I appreciate your thorough explanation Bob. If you don't mind answering two more questions. After completing the course, what other material did you study to gain additional knowledge and how confident do you feel about using the ML techniques on your own problems?﻿
author: Lemuel Uhuru

text: +Lemuel Uhuru My goal now is not to focus directly on ML, but to develop a broad background of related topics (Algorithms, discrete optimization, etc.). Start with Wikipedia and do Web searches on individual topics. CS290c, CS229. Lots of Ng's papers are available (coatesabbeelng_icml2008.pdf, iser04-invertedflight.pdf, nips05-learnvehiculardynamics.pdf, etc.). I don't know your background, so you're going to have to search for material that builds on what you know. For tools, you need Python and Octave (free Matlab). Understand the topics in Segaran's "Collective Intelligence" and you'll also build a working knowledge of Python. The goal is to build a big "bag of tricks". Good luck!﻿
author: Bob Crunch

text: Bob, I have a background in CE, so I'll be building from there, thanks for the resources and GL to you as well.﻿
author: Lemuel Uhuru

text: Hey Lemuel, I hope its not too late for this comment. I took the Coursera class and as was stated by Bob some of the lectures and homework assignments were very technical and required thought and a good understanding of the material. However, I have noticed that the Coursera version is not as rigorous as the real class. This is not to say, however, that the Coursera version is bad, as the class is truly amazing and I highly recommend it. ﻿

author: Martin Jenkins

text: If that's too hard, try this. I'm thinking of two numbers. The sum of those numbers is 100. What are the numbers? Can you do that? I'll make it easier for you - both numbers are non-negative and I want a unique solution.﻿
author: Martin Jenkins

text:
It is you who is the clueless troll. What you describe is not even the cocktail problem. The signals are mixed when they arrive at the two sensors. The degree of mixing and, in the real world, the source to sensor delays are unknown. Here are two sequences of numbers. They represent varying two varying signals received at two sensors. You tell me what the original sequences were. Use as many transistors as you like.

10 10
10 10
10 10

That should be trivial for someone with your skills.﻿
author: Martin Jenkins

text:
You *do* need to read "that" because you *clearly* don't know what you're talking about.

You haven't actually said anything concrete for me to "shown" the errors. You claim it can be done with 3 transistors; you then say a simple amplifier, so it's a simple differencing. This will not work. Show me some algebra if you think it will.

You don't understand the problem (Dunning-Kruger) & won't do the required reading so have resorted to name calling. You have the debating skills of a small child.﻿
author: Martin Jenkins

text: And, on the off chance that you manage to make a neuron with three transistors, you might like to read MInsky & Papert on the discriminatory abilities of perceptrons. When you've done that, you can come back and explain how your single neuron is different. I'm all ears...﻿
author: Martin Jenkins

text: It's 40 years since I learned how to do that, but I see what you're getting at. You're under the illusion a simple difference amplifier will solve the cocktail party problem. It will not. A hearing aid that enhances voice in a noisy situation contains about 10 million transistors. Human and animal brains use thousands of neurons to do this. I suggest you do some reading; you willl find that it is you who is the cluless moron. You're a classic case of the Dunning-Kruger effect. ﻿
